title: 112_s3077
content: The Act is titled the "Pro Football Hall of Fame Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The Pro Football Hall of Fame was established to honor individuals who have made significant contributions to professional football, preserve its history, educate the public, and promote positive values. It opened on September 7, 1963, with a charter class of 17 legends. Membership is represented by a bronze bust, a gold jacket, and a ring. The Pro Football Hall of Fame, established in 1963, has grown to a 118,000-square-foot facility with expansions and renovations over the years. It houses the world's largest collection on professional football, including over 20,000 artifacts and 20 million pages of documents. The museum reaches nearly 15 million people annually through visitors and participants in events. The Pro Football Hall of Fame reaches nearly 15 million people annually through various channels such as museum visits, events, televised programs, website, social media, and educational outreach programs. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins will be legal tender according to the United States Code. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items under the United States Code. The coins minted under this Act will have designs emblematic of professional football, with inscriptions including the year "2016" and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5 of the Act specifies that coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single mint facility during a 1-year period starting January 1, 2016. SEC. 6 addresses the sale of these coins. SEC. 6 of the Act outlines the sale of coins, including pricing, bulk sales, and accepting prepaid orders. The coins will be sold at a price that includes face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount as well. All sales of coins issued under this Act will include surcharges of $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half-dollar coin. The surcharges will be promptly paid to the Pro Football Hall of Fame for construction and renovation. The Hall of Fame will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge will be included if it exceeds the annual commemorative coin program limit. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance for programs issued in a year to exceed the annual commemorative coin program limit.
